DOC.HEAD: Roman Catholic Bishops Say Invasion Destroying Panama
DOC.TEXT: The Roman Catholic Church called on the United States Saturday to end its military action promptly, saying the attack had ``trampled'' on Panama's sovereignty and caused death, destruction and hunger. ``Even though the action was aimed at bringing freedom to all Panamanians, we cannot help but lament the deep wound inflicted to our free and sovereign country and the enormous human and material damages it has caused, especially among the poor,'' said a communique from the nation's Roman Catholic bishops that was read by Archbishop Marcos McGrath. The church asked that food and medicine be sent to the embattled nation following a four-day looting spree that created shortages after Wednesday's assault on Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's forces. The Panamanian people are ``living through an invasion and days of ncertainty because of the U.S. military action that was undertaken with the declared intention of toppling a dictatorial regime and installing democracy,'' the statement said. Although the church has strongly opposed Noriega, the statement did not mention the general by name. He was toppled by U.S. troops and a new government installed, but remains at large. The church also asked the United States to ``end their military action as soon as possible'' and that the newly installed civilian government restore order and create a new police force to stop rampant looting. ``It hurts us that Panamanian and foreign blood has been spilled on our soil,'' it said. ``It hurts us because our nationality, our Panamanian sovereignty has been trampled.''
